body:
# Goban

A fast and efficient QR Code encoder library written purely in Crystal. It uses less heap allocations than other implementations in Crystal, and it is more feature-complete with support for Kanji mode encoding.

The encoder implementation is based on [ISO/IEC 18004:2015](https://www.iso.org/standard/62021.html), and the text segmentation algorithm is based on [Optimal text segmentation for QR Codes](https://www.nayuki.io/page/optimal-text-segmentation-for-qr-codes).

The name comes from the board game [Go](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Go_(game)) (No, not that programming language!), which have inspired the QR Code inventor to come up with a fast and accurate matrix barcode to read. Goban is the name of the [Go board](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Go_equipment#Board) in Japanese.

## Benchmark

Comparing op/s and heap allocations between Goban and [spider-gazelle/qr-code](https://github.com/spider-gazelle/qr-code)

```crystal
require "benchmark"
require "qr-code"
require "goban"

Benchmark.ips do |x|
  x.report("qr-code") { QRCode.new("Hello World!", level: :h) }
  x.report("goban") { Goban::QRCode.encode_string("Hello World!", Goban::QRCode::ECLevel::High) }
end
```

```
qr-code   2.14k (467.30µs) (± 0.69%)   149kB/op   2.12× slower
  goban   4.55k (219.94µs) (± 0.54%)  2.71kB/op        fastest
```

## Installation

1. Add the dependency to your `shard.yml`:

   ```yaml
   dependencies:
     goban:
       github: soya-daizu/goban
   ```

2. Run `shards install`

## Usage

```crystal
require "goban"

qr = Goban::QRCode.encode_string("Hello World!", Goban::QRCode::ECLevel::Low)
qr.print_to_console
# => ██████████████  ████    ██  ██████████████
#    ██          ██    ██    ██  ██          ██
#    ██  ██████  ██  ██  ██  ██  ██  ██████  ██
#    ██  ██████  ██  ██    ██    ██  ██████  ██
#    ██  ██████  ██  ██████      ██  ██████  ██
#    ██          ██              ██          ██
#    ██████████████  ██  ██  ██  ██████████████
#                      ████                    
#    ████████    ██  ██  ██    ██    ██████  ██
#    ██████████    ██  ██    ██████████████  ██
#        ██    ████    ██    ████  ██      ████
#    ████  ██      ██████    ██    ██  ██  ██  
#    ████  ██████████  ██████  ████          ██
#                    ████████    ████    ██  ██
#    ██████████████      ██    ████████        
#    ██          ██    ██████████  ██  ████    
#    ██  ██████  ██    ██  ██          ██████  
#    ██  ██████  ██  ██  ██  ██  ██    ██████  
#    ██  ██████  ██  ██████  ██    ██    ██    
#    ██          ██  ██    ██  ████████      ██
#    ██████████████  ██    ██  ██████    ██    
```

To generate a PNG image, add [stumpy_png](https://github.com/stumpycr/stumpy_png) as a dependency in your shard.yml, and `require "goban/exporters/png"` to use `PNGExporter`.

```crystal
require "goban/exporters/png"

qr = Goban::QRCode.encode_string("Hello World!")
puts "Exporting with targeted size: 500"
size = Goban::PNGExporter.export(qr, "output.png", 500)
puts "Actual QR Code size: #{size}"
```

See [API docs](https://soya-daizu.github.io/goban/) for more details.

## Contributing

1. Fork it (<https://github.com/soya-daizu/goban/fork>)
2. Create your feature branch (`git checkout -b my-new-feature`)
3. Commit your changes (`git commit -am 'Add some feature'`)
4. Push to the branch (`git push origin my-new-feature`)
5. Create a new Pull Request

## Contributors

- [soya_daizu](https://github.com/soya-daizu) - creator and maintainer

types.name: BitStream
types.doc:
An array data structure that holds bits.
Based on the `BitArray` object of the standard library.
types.summary: An array data structure that holds bits.

instance_methods.name: bits
instance_methods.doc: Pointer to the underlying UInt8 representation.
instance_methods.summary: Pointer to the underlying UInt8 representation.

instance_methods.name: size
instance_methods.doc: Size of the array.
instance_methods.summary: Size of the array.

instance_methods.name: tail_idx
instance_methods.doc:
Current tail index of the array. This increases as
more bits are added to itself.
instance_methods.summary: Current tail index of the array.

instance_methods.name: to_s
instance_methods.doc: Same as `#inspect(io)`.
instance_methods.summary: Same as #inspect(io).

def.name: to_s
def.body:
(io << "Goban::BitStream(@tail_idx=") << @tail_idx
io << ", @bits=["
idx = 0
each_slice(4) do |bits|
  if idx == 0
  else
    io << ' '
  end
  bits.each do |bit|
    if idx == @tail_idx
      io << '\''
    end
    io << (bit ? '1' : '0')
    idx = idx + 1
  end
end
io << "])"

types.name: PNGExporter
types.doc: Helper module to generate PNG image for the QR Code object. Requires `stumpy_png` as a dependency.
types.summary: Helper module to generate PNG image for the QR Code object.

instance_methods.name: export
instance_methods.doc:
Generates a PNG image with the given module size and blank modules, and exportes to the
given path.

`mod_size` refers to the number of pixels used for each module in the QR Code symbol,
and `blank_mods` is the size of the white border around the symbol.
instance_methods.summary: Generates a PNG image with the given module size and blank modules, and exportes to the given path.
instance_methods.args_string: (qr : QRCode, path : String, mod_size : Int, blank_mods : Int)
instance_methods.args_html: (qr : QRCode, path : String, mod_size : Int, blank_mods : Int)

def.name: export
def.body:
blank_size = blank_mods * mod_size
size = (qr.size * mod_size) + (blank_size * 2)
dark_color = RGBA.from_rgb_n(0, 0, 0, 8)
light_color = RGBA.from_rgb_n(255, 255, 255, 8)
canvas = Canvas.new(size, size, light_color)
qr.size.times do |x|
  qr.size.times do |y|
    if qr.canvas.get_module(x, y)
    else
      next
    end
    canvas_x = (mod_size * x) + blank_size
    canvas_y = (mod_size * y) + blank_size
    mod_size.times do |i|
      mod_size.times do |j|
        canvas[canvas_x + i, canvas_y + j] = dark_color
      end
    end
  end
end
StumpyPNG.write(canvas, path)
size

instance_methods.name: export
instance_methods.doc:
Generates a PNG image with the given target size and exports to the given path.
Note that the size of the resulting image may not be equal to the target size specified.
instance_methods.summary: Generates a PNG image with the given target size and exports to the given path.

def.name: export
def.body:
size = qr.size + (4 * 2)
ratio = target_size / size
self.export(qr, path, ratio.round.to_i, 4)

types.name: QRCode
types.doc: Object that represents an encoded QR Code symbol.
types.summary: Object that represents an encoded QR Code symbol.

class_methods.name: encode_segments
class_methods.doc:
Creates a new QR Code object for the given data segments, error correction level, and QR Code
version that is large enough to contain all the data in the segments.
Use `PNGExporter` to generate the PNG image from the QR Code object generated.

```
segments = [
  Goban::Segment.alphanumeric("HELLO WORLD"),
  Goban::Segment.bytes("!")
]
qr = Goban::QRCode.encode_segments(segments, Goban::QRCode::ECLevel::Low, Goban::QRCode::Version.new(1))
qr.print_to_console
# => ██████████████    ██  ████  ██████████████
#    ██          ██    ██████    ██          ██
#    ██  ██████  ██  ████  ████  ██  ██████  ██
#    ██  ██████  ██    ██  ██    ██  ██████  ██
#    ██  ██████  ██      ██  ██  ██  ██████  ██
#    ██          ██          ██  ██          ██
#    ██████████████  ██  ██  ██  ██████████████
#                    ████  ████                
#    ██████  ████████████████  ████      ██    
#        ██    ██                    ██      ██
#      ████  ██  ████████    ██████  ████      
#      ██  ██  ██  ████████    ██  ██  ██████  
#        ██  ██████  ██      ██  ██████  ██  ██
#                    ██  ████  ██        ██  ██
#    ██████████████  ████████    ████  ████    
#    ██          ██  ████  ████    ██  ██      
#    ██  ██████  ██  ████████    ██████████████
#    ██  ██████  ██        ██  ██████      ██  
#    ██  ██████  ██  ██      ██  ████  ██    ██
#    ██          ██  ████████          ██  ████
#    ██████████████  ██      ██  ████        ██
```

When constructing your own segments, note that it may not result in the segments that has the
shortest data length even if for each character in the source string you choose an encoding type
with the smallest character set that supports that supports it.
class_methods.summary: Creates a new QR Code object for the given data segments, error correction level, and QR Code version that is large enough to contain all the data in the segments.

def.name: encode_segments
def.body:
bit_stream = BitStream.new((version.max_data_codewords(ecl)) * 8)
segments.each do |segment|
  bit_stream.append_segment_bits(segment, version)
end
bit_stream.append_terminator_bits(version, ecl)
bit_stream.append_padding_bits
data_codewords = RSGenerator.add_ec_codewords(bit_stream.to_bytes, version, ecl)
canvas = Canvas.new(version, ecl)
canvas.draw_function_patterns
canvas.draw_data_codewords(data_codewords)
canvas.apply_best_mask
self.new(version, ecl, canvas)

class_methods.name: encode_string
class_methods.doc:
Creates a new QR Code object for the given string and error correction level.
Setting a higher error correction level makes the QR Code symbol mode resistant
to loss of pixels, but it requires more redundant bits, resulting in a larger
symbol size.
Use `PNGExporter` to generate the PNG image from the QR Code object generated.

```
qr = Goban::QRCode.encode_string("Hello World!", Goban::QRCode::ECLevel::Low)
qr.print_to_console
# => ██████████████  ████    ██  ██████████████
#    ██          ██    ██    ██  ██          ██
#    ██  ██████  ██  ██  ██  ██  ██  ██████  ██
#    ██  ██████  ██  ██    ██    ██  ██████  ██
#    ██  ██████  ██  ██████      ██  ██████  ██
#    ██          ██              ██          ██
#    ██████████████  ██  ██  ██  ██████████████
#                      ████                    
#    ████████    ██  ██  ██    ██    ██████  ██
#    ██████████    ██  ██    ██████████████  ██
#        ██    ████    ██    ████  ██      ████
#    ████  ██      ██████    ██    ██  ██  ██  
#    ████  ██████████  ██████  ████          ██
#                    ████████    ████    ██  ██
#    ██████████████      ██    ████████        
#    ██          ██    ██████████  ██  ████    
#    ██  ██████  ██    ██  ██          ██████  
#    ██  ██████  ██  ██  ██  ██  ██    ██████  
#    ██  ██████  ██  ██████  ██    ██    ██    
#    ██          ██  ██    ██  ████████      ██
#    ██████████████  ██    ██  ██████    ██    
```

QR Code data under the hood is encoded in one or more encoding types, such as Numeric,
Alphanumeric, Byte, and Kanji. Each encoding type has a different set of characters
supported. While Byte mode can express arbitrary types of data (usually interpreted as UTF-8
text, thus it can express any Unicode characters), it often uses more bits to represent a single
codepoint compared to other encoding types which have a limited set of characters supported,
resulting in larger data size and a more challenging QR Code to scan.

This string encoding uses an algorithm to figure out the best segmentation of the encoding
types for the given string to make the resulting data size as small as possible. Here are the
examples:

```
# These examples are the optimal segmentations when the ECLevel is Medium.
# Note that the Segment object shown in these examples are not the actual Segment object used
# in the Goban's codebase but they are just pseudo objects.

"0123456789" # => [Segment("0123456789", mode: Numeric)]
"ABCDEF" # => [Segment("ABCDEF", mode: Alphanumeric)]
"012345A" # => [Segment("012345A", mode: Alphanumeric)]
"0123456A" # => [Segment("0123456", mode: Numeric), Segment("A", mode: Alphanumeric)]
"こんにちwa、世界！ 123"
# => [
#   Segment("こんにち", mode: Kanji),
#   Segment("wa", mode: Byte),
#   Segment("、世界！", mode: Kanji),
#   Segment(" 123", mode: Alphanumeric)
# ]
```

If the type of characters used in your data strings is always the same, you may want to consider
building data segments by yourself so that Goban doesn't have to do extra processing to figure
it out every single time. See `#encode_segments` for how to create QR Codes by manually creating
encoding segments.
class_methods.summary: Creates a new QR Code object for the given string and error correction level.

def.name: encode_string
def.body:
segments, version = Segment::Optimizer.make_optimized_segments(text, ecl)
self.encode_segments(segments, ecl, version)

instance_methods.name: canvas
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the canvas of the QR Code symbol. Canvas contains information about
each single module (pixel) in the symbol.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the canvas of the QR Code symbol.

instance_methods.name: ecl
instance_methods.doc: Error correction level of the QR Code symbol.
instance_methods.summary: Error correction level of the QR Code symbol.

instance_methods.name: print_to_console
instance_methods.doc:
Prints the QR Code symbol as a text in the console. To generate the actual image file,
use `PNGExporter` or write your own exporter by reading each modules in `#canvas`.
instance_methods.summary: Prints the QR Code symbol as a text in the console.

instance_methods.name: size
instance_methods.doc: Length of a side in the symbol.
instance_methods.summary: Length of a side in the symbol.

instance_methods.name: version
instance_methods.doc:
Version of the QR Code symbol. Version in QR Code does not refer to its revision,
but simply indicates the size format of the QR Code symbol.
instance_methods.summary: Version of the QR Code symbol.

types.name: Canvas
types.doc: Holds information about each modules in a QR Code symbol.
types.summary: Holds information about each modules in a QR Code symbol.

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc: Creates a blank canvas with the given version and error correction level.
constructors.summary: Creates a blank canvas with the given version and error correction level.

instance_methods.name: get_module
instance_methods.doc: Returns whether a module at the given coordinate is dark or not.
instance_methods.summary: Returns whether a module at the given coordinate is dark or not.

instance_methods.name: module_reserved?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns whether a module at the given coordinate is reserved for
it being a part of function patterns.
instance_methods.summary: Returns whether a module at the given coordinate is reserved for it being a part of function patterns.

instance_methods.name: print_to_console
instance_methods.doc: Prints the modules on the canvas as a text in the console.
instance_methods.summary: Prints the modules on the canvas as a text in the console.

def.name: print_to_console
def.body:
@size.times do |y|
  @size.times do |x|
    print(get_module(x, y) ? "██" : "  ")
  end
  print('\n')
end
print('\n')

types.name: ECLevel
types.doc:
Error correction level of the QR Code.
QR Code symbols include redundant bits based on the selected error
correction level, so that even if some part the symbol is not readable,
the decoder can recover the loss for up to:

- 7% for `Low`
- 15% for `Medium`
- 25% for `Quartile`
- 30% for `High`

Note that choosing a higher error correction level requires more redundant
bits, meaning that the resulting QR Code symbol can get larger.
types.summary: Error correction level of the QR Code.

instance_methods.name: value
instance_methods.doc: Mask identifier. Valid values are integers from 0 to 7.
instance_methods.summary: Mask identifier.

types.name: Version
types.doc:
Represents a version number of the QR Code symbol.
Possible versions range from 1 to 40, and the higher the number,
the large the size of the final QR Code symbol.
types.summary: Represents a version number of the QR Code symbol.

instance_methods.doc:
The comparison operator. Returns `0` if the two objects are equal,
a negative number if this object is considered less than *other*,
a positive number if this object is considered greater than *other*,
or `nil` if the two objects are not comparable.

Subclasses define this method to provide class-specific ordering.

The comparison operator is usually used to sort values:

```
# Sort in a descending way:
[3, 1, 2].sort { |x, y| y <=> x } # => [3, 2, 1]

# Sort in an ascending way:
[3, 1, 2].sort { |x, y| x <=> y } # => [1, 2, 3]
```
instance_methods.summary: The comparison operator.

instance_methods.name: alignment_pattern_positions
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a list of the alignment pattern positions for thie version.
The list may include positions in which drawing is not allowed due
to overlap with the finder pattern, etc.
instance_methods.summary: Returns a list of the alignment pattern positions for thie version.

def.name: alignment_pattern_positions
def.body:
v = @value
if v == 1
  return [] of Int32
end
g = (v // 7) + 2
step = v == 32 ? 26 : ((((v * 4) + (g * 2)) + 1) // ((g * 2) - 2)) * 2
result = (0...(g - 1)).map do |i|
  (symbol_size - 7) - (i * step)
end
result.push(6)
result.reverse!
result

instance_methods.name: max_data_codewords
instance_methods.doc:
Maximum number of codewords that can be contained in the QR Code
symbol of this version.
instance_methods.summary: Maximum number of codewords that can be contained in the QR Code symbol of this version.

instance_methods.name: raw_data_mods_count
instance_methods.doc:
Number of the modules that are available for writing the actual
data payload.
instance_methods.summary: Number of the modules that are available for writing the actual data payload.

def.name: raw_data_mods_count
def.body:
v = @value
g = v // 7
timing_pattern_mod = timing_pattern_mods_count * 2
if v == 1
  align_pattern_mod = 0
else
  n = g + 1
  align_pattern_mod = 25 * (((n ** 2) + (2 * n)) - 2)
end
overlaps = g * 10
func_pattern_mod = ((192 + timing_pattern_mod) + align_pattern_mod) - overlaps
fvi_mod = v < 7 ? 31 : 67
((symbol_size ** 2) - func_pattern_mod) - fvi_mod

instance_methods.name: symbol_size
instance_methods.doc: Size of the QR Code symbol for this version.
instance_methods.summary: Size of the QR Code symbol for this version.

instance_methods.name: timing_pattern_mods_count
instance_methods.doc: Number of the timing pattern modules for this version.
instance_methods.summary: Number of the timing pattern modules for this version.

types.name: RSGenerator
types.doc: Module for generating redundant Reed-Solomon error correction bits.
types.summary: Module for generating redundant Reed-Solomon error correction bits.

def.name: add_ec_codewords
def.body:
if codewords.size != (version.max_data_codewords(ecl))
  raise("Codewords size mismatch")
end
ec_blocks_count = ERROR_CORRECTION_BLOCKS[ecl.value][version.value]
block_ecc_size = ECC_CODEWORDS_PER_BLOCK[ecl.value][version.value]
raw_codewords = version.raw_data_mods_count // 8
short_blocks_count = ec_blocks_count - (raw_codewords % ec_blocks_count)
short_block_size = raw_codewords // ec_blocks_count
blocks = Array(Array(UInt8)).new(ec_blocks_count)
gen_poly = self.get_generator_polynomial(block_ecc_size)
k = 0
ec_blocks_count.times do |i|
  data_size = (short_block_size - block_ecc_size) + (i >= short_blocks_count ? 1 : 0)
  data = codewords[k, data_size].to_a
  k = k + data_size
  ec_codewords = self.poly_modulo(data, gen_poly)
  if i < short_blocks_count
    data.push(0)
  end
  data.concat(ec_codewords)
  blocks.push(data)
end
result = Array(UInt8).new(raw_codewords)
(short_block_size + 1).times do |i|
  blocks.each_with_index do |block, j|
    if (i != (short_block_size - block_ecc_size)) || j >= short_blocks_count
      result.push(block[i])
    end
  end
end
result

types.name: Segment
types.doc: Represents a segment of QR Code data that holds its data bits and encoding type.
types.summary: Represents a segment of QR Code data that holds its data bits and encoding type.

class_methods.name: alphanumeric
class_methods.doc: Shorthand method for creating a Alphanumeric mode segment.
class_methods.summary: Shorthand method for creating a Alphanumeric mode segment.

def.name: alphanumeric
def.body:
chars = text.chars.map do |c|
  (ALPHANUMERIC_CHARS.index(c)) || (raise("Alphanumeric data contains unencodable characters"))
end
bit_stream = BitStream.new((chars.size * 5) + ((chars.size + 1) // 2))
segment = self.new(Segment::Mode::Alphanumeric, chars.size, bit_stream)
chars.each_slice(2) do |slice|
  if slice.size == 1
    val = slice[0]
    size = 6
  else
    val = (slice[0] * 45) + slice[1]
    size = 11
  end
  bit_stream.append_bits(val, size)
end
segment

class_methods.name: bytes
class_methods.doc: Shorthand method for creating a Byte mode segment.
class_methods.summary: Shorthand method for creating a Byte mode segment.

def.name: bytes
def.body:
bytes = text.bytes
bit_stream = BitStream.new(bytes.size * 8)
segment = self.new(Segment::Mode::Byte, bytes.size, bit_stream)
bytes.each do |byte|
  bit_stream.append_bits(byte, 8)
end
segment

class_methods.name: count_total_bits
class_methods.doc: Count number of bits in the given list of segments.
class_methods.summary: Count number of bits in the given list of segments.

def.name: count_total_bits
def.body:
result = 0
segments.each do |segment|
  cci_bits_size = segment.mode.cci_bits_size(version)
  if segment.char_count >= (1 << cci_bits_size)
    raise("Segment too long")
  end
  result = result + ((4 + cci_bits_size) + segment.bit_stream.size)
end
result

class_methods.name: kanji
class_methods.doc: Shorthand method for creating a Kanji mode segment.
class_methods.summary: Shorthand method for creating a Kanji mode segment.

def.name: kanji
def.body:
bytes = text.encode("SHIFT_JIS")
if (bytes.size % 2) == 0
else
  raise("Kanji data contains unencodable characters")
end
bit_stream = BitStream.new((bytes.size // 2) * 13)
segment = self.new(Segment::Mode::Kanji, text.size, bit_stream)
(bytes.each_slice(2)).each do |byte_pair|
  if (!((64..252).includes?(byte_pair[1]))) || (byte_pair[1] == 127)
    raise("Kanji data contains unencodable characters")
  end
  val = (byte_pair[0].to_u16 << 8) | byte_pair[1]
  if (33088..40956).includes?(val)
    val = val - 33088
  else
    if (57408..60351).includes?(val)
      val = val - 49472
    else
      raise("Kanji data contains unencodable characters")
    end
  end
  val = ((val >> 8) * 192) + (val & 255)
  bit_stream.append_bits(val, 13)
end
segment

class_methods.name: numeric
class_methods.doc: Shorthand method for creating a Numeric mode segment.
class_methods.summary: Shorthand method for creating a Numeric mode segment.

def.name: numeric
def.body:
digits = text.chars
if digits.all?(&.ascii_number?)
else
  raise("Numeric data contains non-numeric characters")
end
bit_stream = BitStream.new((digits.size * 3) + ((digits.size + 2) // 3))
segment = self.new(Segment::Mode::Numeric, digits.size, bit_stream)
digits.each_slice(3) do |slice|
  val = slice.join.to_u32
  bit_stream.append_bits(val, (slice.size * 3) + 1)
end
segment

def.name: new
def.body:
case mode
when .numeric?
  self.numeric(text)
when .alphanumeric?
  self.alphanumeric(text)
when .byte?
  self.bytes(text)
when .kanji?
  self.kanji(text)
else
  raise("Unsupported mode")
end

types.name: Mode
types.doc: Represents a encoding mode of a data segment.
types.summary: Represents a encoding mode of a data segment.

types.name: Optimizer
types.doc:
Module for optimizing segmentations of the encoding modes for
the given text.
types.summary: Module for optimizing segmentations of the encoding modes for the given text.

instance_methods.name: make_optimized_segments
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a tuple of the optimized segments and QR Code version
for the given text and error correction level.
instance_methods.summary: Returns a tuple of the optimized segments and QR Code version for the given text and error correction level.

def.name: make_optimized_segments
def.body:
chars = text.chars
segments, version = nil, nil
used_bits = 0
(QRCode::Version::MIN..QRCode::Version::MAX).each do |v|
  v = QRCode::Version.new(v)
  if ((v == 1) || (v == 10)) || (v == 27)
    char_modes = compute_char_modes(chars, v)
    segments = make_segments(text, char_modes)
  end
  if segments
  else
    raise("Segment optimization failed")
  end
  cap_bits = (v.max_data_codewords(ecl)) * 8
  used_bits = Segment.count_total_bits(segments, v)
  if used_bits <= cap_bits
    version = v
    break
  end
end
if segments && version
else
  raise("Text too long")
end
{segments, version}
